Investment conclusion: We reiterate our OW and raise our PT to $264, predicated on 15x our 2027E EBITDA. We are encouraged by MTZ's consistent execution and margin improvement, supported by strong demand across Communications, Pipeline Infrastructure, and Power Delivery. Operating leverage, disciplined project selection, and strategic M&A optionality position MTZ for sustained margin expansion and a potential multiple re-rating as confidence in its multi-year growth outlook builds.

4Q25 earnings outlook: We expect MTZ to deliver a solid 4Q, supported by strong execution in Communications and Pipeline Infrastructure, offsetting seasonal softness in Power Delivery and CE&I. We match 4Q guidance. MTZ posted 1.1x BTB in 3Q and expects to book the second large transmission award in 4Q, with revenue contribution starting mid-2026. Pipeline bookings remain robust, with $700M added in 3Q and visibility improving despite the book-and-burn nature of the segment. Management is likely to reiterate confidence in multi-year growth drivers and provide incremental detail on Greenlink permitting progress and the new transmission project. Cash generation should accelerate in 4Q, supporting strategic flexibility heading into 2026.

2026 outlook: Management has an informal 2026 framework calling for ~10% revenue growth, ~20% EBITDA growth, and ~25% EPS growth, driven by broad-based strength across segments. Pipeline Infrastructure is a key driver with DD% growth expected in 2026 and a sharper step-up in 2027. Communications should see strong growth from FTTH, BEAD, and fiber expansion, with margin improvement as mix and execution improve. CE&I benefits from robust renewables visibility, aided by tax credits and rising battery attach rates, while Power Delivery remains solid with Greenlink and a second large transmission project adding upside. MTZ reiterated confidence in sustaining HSD-LDD% organic growth through 2027-2028, citing strong end-market fundamentals and operating leverage opportunities that could drive consolidated EBITDA margins toward DD over time. With a net leverage target of 1.5-2.0x signaling dry powder, MTZ is well positioned to pursue tuck-in M&A focused on enhancing execution

capabilities and expanding its self-perform platform. A T&D acquisition could also be possible to further boost its power delivery capabilities. We view 2026 as a year of margin expansion and accelerating growth, setting the stage for a multi-year re-rating. Investment conclusion: The Company has emerged from a year of execution challenges into a year of +HSD core growth in both segments with margins within the LT guided ranges and room to run beyond that. We maintain that MYRG has come a long way from the project execution and has successfully realigned the business back to its core growth and margin objectives. At current valuation, we believe the shares are fairly valued and we maintain SW.

4Q25 earnings outlook: MYRG does not provide formal guidance, but we expect management to reiterate segment margin targets and provide color on backlog trends. Our estimates assume +HSD growth in core T&D and C&I, with reported T&D revenue flat to slightly down as challenged clean energy projects roll off. C&I growth should remain strong, supported by multi-year transportation and airport projects announced earlier in the year, as well as continued momentum in data centers and advanced manufacturing. Margins are expected to trend toward the middle of the target ranges (7-10.5% for T&D and 5-7.5% for C&I), aided by improved execution and completion of problem projects. MYRG ended 3Q with $2.67B of backlog and 1.0x BTB in both segments, and management highlighted steady bidding activity in T&D and multiple awards in C&I across core markets.

2026 outlook: Management's updated commentary points to 10% revenue growth in 2026 across both segments, supported by a constructive bidding environment and strong C&I market momentum. MYRG raised its C&I margin expectations to 5-7.5% (from 4-6%) while maintaining the T&D margin range of 7-10.5%, reflecting confidence in execution and mix improvement. Backlog visibility remains solid, with MSAs contributing ~60% of T&D revenue and a growing pipeline of large transmission projects for 2027+, including 500 kV and 765 kV opportunities. C&I continues to benefit from secular demand drivers in data centers, healthcare, clean energy, and transportation, with recent awards reinforcing market strength. MYRG's disciplined project selection and efficiency gains should support margin expansion beyond the midpoint of target ranges over time. With net leverage near zero, strong FCF, and an available credit facility, MYRG is well positioned to pursue M&A in ancillary services or resume share repurchases. We see 2026 as a year of normalized growth

and margin recovery, with execution on these targets critical given the recent multiple expansion. Sources: KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc., FactSet Note: Specialty contractor comps: DY, MTZ, PRIM, PWR. Investment conclusion: We maintain our OW rating on PRIM and continue to see meaningful upside as the Company leverages its leadership in utility-scale renewables and storage, expands its power delivery footprint, and benefits from secular growth in communications, and natural gas generation. Our PT of $158 is based on 13.5x 2027E EBITDA. We believe the pieces for strong growth in 2026 are firmly in place, supported by renewables, natural gas generation, and pipeline opportunities. As core growth verticals take a larger share of revenue and margin expansion follows, we see PRIM well positioned for outsized value creation.

4Q25 earnings outlook: We expect PRIM to deliver results at or above the recently raised 2025 guidance midpoint. Management has guided to GM of 10-12% for both segments, and we expect incremental improvements in 2026 as pipeline projects normalize, and renewables execution stabilizes. Bookings will be the key focus as energy BTB was soft in 3Q on timing delays, but management indicated several bookings closed in 4Q and expects a 1.2x or higher BTB for Energy, supported by renewables and gas generation wins (including Fermi). PRIM sees Energy backlog trending toward $3.6B vs. ~$3B currently.

2026 outlook: The 2026 outlook for renewables is more conservative (flat to up vs. prior modest growth expectations) due to potential pushouts tied to design modifications and timing. PRIM is confident in 2026 bookings momentum including those in natural gas generation and pipeline work which remain key growth drivers, with >$3B in pipeline opportunities over the next 12 months and incremental bookings expected in early 2026. Communications continues to provide steady growth and represents upside as fiber and DC-related work expands. New CEO Koti Vadlamudi will join the 4Q call and is expected to set the tone for 2026, including potential LT targets and a refreshed growth outlook at a CMD in 2026. With net leverage near zero and strong cash generation, PRIM has flexibility to pursue strategic acquisitions in T&D and electrical C&I, targeting HSD growth and IRRs north of 12%. We see 2026 as a pivotal year for PRIM, with margin expansion and backlog recovery positioning the Company for sustained

double-digit growth.

Investment conclusion: PWR continues to solidify its status as a high-quality specialty contractor as defined by scale and execution. However, at 20.2x 2027E EBITDA vs. the S&P at ~14.7x, we maintain our view that further multiple re-rating is likely capped in the near term, and we do not see NT estimate upside, ex M&A.

4Q25 earnings outlook: We expect PWR to deliver results broadly in line with guidance, with revenue strength in EIS offsetting margin pressure from UUIS. Key 4Q assumptions include a sequential ramp in EIS revenue driven by solar, storage, and data center projects, continued solid execution in renewables, and a seasonal stepdown in storm restoration activity following a strong 2024 comp. Underground utility work should rebound modestly as large pipeline comps ease and gas utility projects pushed from earlier in the year begin burning. PWR posted a strong 1.4x BTB in 3Q, led by EIS bookings, and management indicated momentum in solar-plus-storage and DC work should continue into year-end. We expect tone on the bid environment to remain constructive, with management reiterating confidence in long-tailed growth opportunities across T&D, renewables, and low-voltage electrical and mechanical scopes. FCF should strengthen in 4Q, aided by working capital normalization.

2026 outlook: We expect PWR to outline a multi-year roadmap at its March Investor Day, with 2026 positioned as a year of continued growth across core segments. While renewables revenue growth will likely moderate after several years of outsized expansion, margin progression remains a key watch point as execution improves and integrated scopes scale. T&D and substation work should sustain MSD-HSD growth, supported by grid hardening, EV penetration, and AI/data center infrastructure buildout, while underground utility rebounds after lapping tough pipeline comps. Large transmission projects and modular construction opportunities represent incremental upside, though timing remains difficult to forecast. Strategic M&A is expected to remain active, focused on targets that align with PWR's self-perform model and expand capabilities in substations, modular, and right-of-way services. With a strong balance sheet and proven ability to deploy capital, PWR is well positioned to deliver DD EPS growth in 2026, supported by scale leverage, backlog

visibility, and continued leadership in integrated energy and infrastructure solutions.

| Backlog                                        | The value of total estimated gross revenues expected to be realized for incomplete contract work or awarded work that has yet to be signed. Revenues in backlog are typically realized over 1-3 years; depending on the size; scale; and scope of the contract awarded                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
|------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Book-to-bill Ratio                             | New awards booked in backlog over earned revenue taken out of backlog                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |
| Remaining Performance Obligation               | The value of total gross revenues expected to be realized for incomplete contract work or work in process , excluding contract work awarded but not yet signed or work able to be canceled without major cost to the customer                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| Master Service Agreement                       | price basis. MSAs usually span 1-3 years but can be terminated by the customer within 30-90 days. As with most reimbursable contract structures , MSA agreements limit margin upside                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| Lump Sum Contract                              | The contractor perfoms adefined scope of work for a specified fee. Revenue is recognized by timing of cost inputs. Higher margin upside but greater risk of cost overruns                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| Unit-Price                                     | The contractor perfoms work at a fixed price per unit of work                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| Cost-Plus Contract                             | Reimbursable; the contractor is for costs incurred plus a negotiated fee or rate. Revenue is recognized when direct costs are incurred plus an applicable fixed fee as of the balance sheet date. Lower margin potential though lower risk profile paid                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| Time and Materials Contract                    | Reimbursable; the contractor negotiates hourly rates and charges dlients based on the actual time that it spent on a project:. Clients also reimburse the contractor for materials and other direct incidental expenditures incumred                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) Contract        | The contractor guarantees a maximum price for services encompassing the entire project and is reimbursed for project costs plus a fixed fee. The contractor is liable for cost overruns or delay costs that exceed the GMP . Revenue is recognized as costs are incurred; relative to total estimated project costs                                                                                                                                                                                           |
| Indefinite Deliveryllndefinite Quantity (IDIQ) | Multi-award contract vehicle in which several contractors are selected to provide an indefinite quantity of services over a pre-determined number of base years plus an extension option (option years).  The government obligates funds for a minimum guaranteed amount and places task orders a basic contract for individual services. Large IDIQ awards can be subject to protests (i.e a rival bidder files a bid protest with the US GAO; staling the award while the Office reviews the claim) against |
| Recompete                                      | The process of re-qualifying for an existing award when the original performance period for a contract ends                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
| Costs in Excess of Billing                     | Contract assets; unbilled revenue (typically from long-term contracts) exceeding the amount billed to the customer                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
| Bilings in Excess of Cost                      | Contract liabilities; advance payments, deferred revenue; and customer billings exceeding costs incurred to date                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
